Literature Review: The development of sustainable and efficient energy storage systems is a critical challenge in the transition towards a low-carbon economy. Traditional battery technologies, particularly those based on lithium-ion (Li-ion) chemistry, have been widely adopted due to their high energy density and long cycle life. However, concerns over the availability and environmental impact of strategic metals, such as lithium and cobalt, have spurred interest in alternative electrode materials. Among these, nonconjugated redox-active polymers (NC-RAPs) have emerged as promising candidates due to their cost-effectiveness, good processability, and unique electrochemical properties.
